posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Hey dude,

You may have played for a long time, but in your previous topic and in this one, we can tell that you haven't taken your NWN experience into the depth that we have here at the ECB. No offense, but just the fact that you want to dual-wield Katanas tells us that you don't really know a lot about this game, or else you'd know that katanas are large weapons and you receive a higher penalty for doing so. Or maybe you do know, but the OC is SO EASY that you can finish it dual-wielding Greatswords (you can't, just being sarcastic here ), so you just don't care.

I can tell you this: NWN is THE MOST COMPLEX GAME EVER MADE! The realm of possibilities for Character building is just INFINITE or almost. I can tell you from experience that the OC represents ZERO challenge for a good build, so if you REALLY REALLY REALLY want a Katana dual-wielder, the OC is probably the place to do it.

The power in building strong characters comes from the synergies between the classes, things that you gain from one class that complement the things that you gain from another class. As an example, we can quote Mick Dagger's recently posted Divine Bomber, in the level 20 section. It's SUCH A COOL BUILD! It's a Bard / AA / BG. BG gives him save bonuses, Bull's Strength and Divine Might, AA gives him AB points, which allows him to invest his stat points in Charisma for more DM uses per day and higher damage with the bow. And bard comes in as a requirement for AA, but also brings in the skill points, skill set, the Bard Song and a couple of spells. There are SO MANY SYNERGIES in this build that are VERY WELL EXPLORED by Mick.

The guy you want to make will start with a deficit, he will receive a -4 penalty to each attack in both hands because of the size of the Katana, but NOT JUST THAT!!! He will also need at least 15 DEX to dual-wield (ITWF requires it) unless he goes for Ranger, BUT, being a Katana guy, he will need to be STR-oriented, since Katanas aren't finesseable. Rangers can't wear heavy armor or else they lose their dualwielding properties, so you'll have low AC, even lower because you won't be able to carry a shield, having 2 weapons and all. So, basically, unlike the example I explained above of Mick's build, your build is actually SEVERELY HANDICAPPED from the start because of what you want it to do, which on the plus side can make the OC slightly more challenging.

Anyway, what I want to explain to you is this: If you are going to dual-wield, the most reasonable thing to do would be to go for a light weapon, and since it has a DEX requirement of 15, it's probably a good idea to go for a DEX-based toon, but if you want STR, you can do what I'll explain next: I'm thinking a simple Fighter / Rogue / WM who wields Kukris should be able to get the job done with ease, if you're interested. You could go Fighter 10 Rogue 3 WM 7. Start with 16 STR, 15 DEX (13 +2 from Elf), 14 CON (16 -2 from Elf), 13 INT, 8 WIS and 8 CHA. All stat points go to STR. You have 5 stat increases until level 20, so you'll end up with 20 STR.

I could build you something if you like the idea, but I want to know whether you are willing to let go of the Katana idea first.

Take it EZ!

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Rogue is there for the skill dumps. There is not really another class that you can put in there that will give you that much benefit. Rogue gives you Tumble as a Class Skill and UMD (Use Magic Device), which are just THE TWO MOST IMPORTANT SKILLS IN THE GAME. Tumble adds +8 to AC at level 37 (+1 for every 5 ranks in it) and UMD allows you to cast from scrolls. The only two other classes that give you these two skills as class skills are Bard and Assassin. Bruenor isn't an Assassin kind of guy for sure, and Bard could be OK, but it doesn't give you Sneak Attack or Evasion, so basically, you'll be less effective with Bard than with Rogue. Don't think too much of it, though, the Rogue levels could represent that he has had contact with the "underworld", or "shady dealings" in the past, or just that he is "street safe". having Rogue levels doesn't necessarily make Bruenor an outlaw, you know?

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Hey dude.

Every build is tweakable, you can do that if you want, but I wouldn't. As Valerfor says, you don't really NEED any of that in the OC. I only discovered Tumble gave you AC after finishing HoTU 100 times LOL. The problem with doing things this way is that you would have to drop a feat and you'd lose 1 AB on a build that "technically" is already a low AB build, but like he said, Mephistopheles has 32 AC, so it doesn't even matter. . The only real droppable feats there are: Exotic Weapons and Improved Knockdown. The remaining feats are either requirements for something else (Cleave, Great Cleave and Improved Critical for DevCrit, Power Attack for Cleave, Dodge and Toughness for Dwarven Defender) or VERY USEFUL FEATS (Expertise saves you LOTS OF DEFENSIVE STANCES for the most important battles, KD goes without saying and Blind Fight is ESSENTIAL for all meleers when fighting concealed creatures or when you're blinded. And, this build only has two Rogue levels to spread around 40, so if you choose to take a pre-epic skill dump, you'll suffer later on with the lack of another dump for many levels.

What I would advise you to do is this: if you REALLY value playability that much, change the spread. Add more Rogue levels, in which case you don't even have to use my build, you can go with Grizz's Citadel, which is a VERY POWERFUL build that takes more Rogue for Crippling Strike and is WAY MORE PLAYABLE than mine (well, it's way more powerful until level 22, then mine would be better).

Here's the build:

CLICK HERE

You can do as you please, it's important that you like your character, but I'm just telling you what I think is best. Sometimes you need to do the exact opposite to learn why it is that I'm suggesting what I am and then you'll start understanding not just the advice I'm giving you, but also WHY I'm giving it to you.

EDIT: Just saw your post. Forgot to mention that 724 HP is WITHOUT Defensive Stance.

Now, not knowing the value of UMD is something very common in beginning players. You don't really NEED to buff up for ANY encounter, not even bosses, so it does kind of seem like overkill (and given the level of difficulty you'll be facing, it SURELY IS ). But, trust me when I say, if you EVER go beyond the OC, UMD will be VITAL. It's one thing to go into a battle with a full plate and a weapon, it's another one to go with a Bless potion, an Aid potion, a Stoneskin scroll, a Flame Weapon scroll, an Improved Invisibility scroll, a Bull's Strength scroll, etc.. In some places, those buffs will mean the difference between victory and defeat. Unfortunately for you, the OC is not one of those. Why don't you give that Diablo module that Valerfor mentioned a try? It's going to BLOW YOUR MIND!

Take it EZ!

Hey man!

The picture looks AWESOME!! Can you send me the file? I'd love to add it to my NWN portraits list.

As to your questions, starting with Rogue is good because of skill points, as Valerfor already explained. The fact he starts with Rogue shouldn't prevent you from naming him Bruenor Battlehammer, and his name is Battlehammer, so he should carry a Battlehammer . But, if you want the waraxe, you'll have to drop a feat for it. What would you drop? Probably Improved Knockdown or Improved Critical. Actually, since this build doesn't go for Devastating Critical, there's no reason not to drop Improved Critical. In truth, the difference in weapon isn't going to be worth the feat investment. With a Warhammer, you'll be doing 1d8 damage and critting for 19-20 / x3. With the Dwarven Waraxe, you'll have 1d10 damage critting for 19-20 / x2. One thing that doesn't really matter in the OC but will in other worlds is that Slashing-type damage resistance is way more common than Bludgeoning-type. Not just because of damage belts, but Undead creatures alone have Slashing and Piercing resistance, while no Bludgeoning resistance.

Anyway, if you want to wield a waraxe go for it, but DON'T TAKE THAT FIGHTER LEVEL BEFORE. The reason why that 4th Fighter level is delayed is because you need to wait until the epics to be able to take Epic Weapon Specialization. Since there are only 4 Fighter levels in that build, you have to wait until a general feat level in epics to take that.

The alternative is to change the whole spread of the build, lowering your DR and HP for one more feat and the ability to anticipate the Fighter feats. You can go Fighter 8 Rogue 10 DD 22. You would lose 8 HP, 3 /- Damage Reduction, but gain 1 feat (lose 1 feat from DD 26, gain 2 feats from Fighter 6 and Fighter 8). Then you would be able to take 6 Fighter / 4 Rogue 10 DD pre-epic, getting fewer skill dumps, but gaining 1 BAB and the extra feat you got could be used to get the Exotic Weapons you want so bad. Would you like me to build you that alternative?
